channel.title: Comments on: Umm….No…that is not how you export a table into a file with SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Tahir Khalid
item.dc:creator: Tahir Khalid
item.description: Isn't Oracle one big crazy heap of craziness?
item.content:encoded: Isn’t Oracle one big crazy heap of craziness?

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.content:encoded:
O.M.G.
It sure is creative ðŸ™‚

Crazy stories? Sure I’ll share one.
How about executing a query inside a cursor with count(*). If the count is bigger than 0 (meaning a row is returned), execute the query again, but now with the column needed to populate a variable.

Because the cursor wasn’t bad enough already, they did every query twice ðŸ™‚

ps: like your UmmmNo pic. I might use it someday ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: It is baffling in a way, from all the documented ways that are available why going this path. I mean how do you even find this stuff? It is probably the name Output File that lead them down this rabbit hole
item.content:encoded: It is baffling in a way, from all the documented ways that are available why going this path. I mean how do you even find this stuff? It is probably the name Output File that lead them down this rabbit hole

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: I'm pretty confident you took the award for finding the most creative and stupid method of getting a task done in SQL Server.
item.content:encoded: I’m pretty confident you took the award for finding the most creative and stupid method of getting a task done in SQL Server.
